episode.title: Wisconsin Department of Corrections v. Schacht

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument next in Number 97-461, Wisconsin Department of Corrections v. Schacht.
Mr. Moriarty.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

In this action substantial Federal questions were presented by the individual capacity claims respondent chose to make against Warden Catherine Farrey and the other Wisconsin employees who are defendants in this action.
He sued them personally under a Federal statute, section 1983, alleging violations of the Federal constitution.
Substantial Federal questions were presented.
Had this action proceeded in district court on an initial complaint, the district court would unquestionably have had original jurisdiction because substantial Federal questions were presented.

The potential, had this commenced in district court, the potential that those claims could have been barred by a sovereign immunity defense or any of those claims could have been barred by a sovereign immunity defense would not have affected original jurisdiction of the court.
This case instead was removed.
It arrived by removal rather than an initial complaint.
The analysis--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It was removed, in effect, by the State.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --It was removed by the State and the employees of the State sued both personally and officially.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right.

Now, if you're right that the official capacity claims and the claims against the State involve defendants who aren't persons under section 1983, why didn't the State just waive its Eleventh Amendment immunity?
I mean, you're perfectly safe.
Claims weren't going to go forward under 1983.
Did the State consider waiving the Eleventh Amendment immunity?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Your Honor, there are--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I mean, if you're right, I just don't see why the State didn't do it.
I don't... it doesn't make sense to me.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --We return back to the decision on whether to remove.
The claims as to which sovereign immunity applied were really irrelevant because, whether this case was prosecuted in Federal court or State court, they would have been barred.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, would you answer my question?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: I'm--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did the State waive its immunity?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --It did not waive its immunity.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But your position is those claims against... the official capacity claims and the claims against the State cannot proceed under 1983 because the State isn't a person.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Okay.
So why not waive it?
Why not end this thing?
I just... it's the strangest posture.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: We are now looking back, Your Honor, at... from the perspective of the Seventh Circuit decision at the initial removal decision.

At the time of removal, the claims made against the State were clearly barred either under Will... in both State and Federal court either under Will, because it wasn't within the definition of a person, or based on Eleventh Amendment immunity, or sovereign immunity in State court.
The real crux of the case was the individual capacity claims made against the individual.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And as to that you wanted it tried in Federal court, not State court.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: That's--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So why not waive the Eleventh Amendment immunity?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --Because that's not a price of admission to the Federal court, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, maybe it should be.
If we could start all over, it would seem to me to make some sense that if the State removes, that is a waiver of the Eleventh Amendment.
It seems rather odd that you want to go to a court and then say I don't want to be in the court.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: By joining with the officials sued personally in removing, which is required by the removal statutes, the State is not saying we want to be in... we don't want to be in court.
Obviously, they're in court.
The question is--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you have to consent, as you indicate.
You have to consent to the removal.
You had the option to keep it in State court, but you consented to be removed to a Federal court.
He removed it.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --Certainly it was a litigation decision by all of the defendants joining together, but the sovereign... the Eleventh Amendment is a defense.
It is not part of the initial threshold jurisdictional question.
Is there a substantial Federal question?
Of course there is.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Moriarty, I remember asking the counsel in the Chicago case that we heard, one thinks of Federal courts as being a place where you can get away from local prejudice and that sort of thing, but one would think that the State of Wisconsin would be perfectly happy to be in the State court.
I gather that isn't always the case.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: It isn't always the case in individual cases.
For example, we have strictly Federal constitutional claims here.
A body of Federal constitutional law that has developed, particularly in the Seventh Circuit, where there's binding precedent on the district courts.
There would not be that binding precedent on the State courts.
If, as a litigator--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What difference does it make, so long as you're going to stand on the Eleventh Amendment?

All this knowledge that the Federal courts have about Federal law as far as the State is concerned is irrelevant, and as to that, the last piece of this... I mean, you say we have a right to remand because the Eleventh Amendment is in the nature of a defense.
It's not like the existence of Federal question, jurisdiction or diversity.

The end of the road as far as the State is concerned, as distinguished from the individuals, you... do you concede that the Federal court entertaining your Eleventh Amendment plea should remand rather than dismiss?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --Answering the second question first, I do not concede that.
The Federal court had Federal question jurisdiction.
It had it... it would have had it had an initial complaint been filed.
It had it on removal.
It is inappropriate for the court to remand claims that are properly before it and that were properly dismissed by the district court through that... through the full litigation that occurred.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But then I don't understand, because what you're saying by your Eleventh Amendment plea, the Eleventh Amendment not applying in the State court whatever State immunity applies, that you cannot be sued any place, that you are just totally immune, because you do this, you go over to the Federal court and say, Federal court, you can't touch it because of the Eleventh Amendment and dismiss the case, and then no one can touch it.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Right.
The... when the Eleventh Amendment applies, generally it's dismissal without prejudice, such that if it--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But then you do this over and over again.
It's without prejudice.
Yes.
Then you begin again in the State court, and then you remove it, and you could do that over and over again.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --We had here, however, claims under section 1983 that were barred in any court regardless.
The State court, the Federal court would have barred--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But that's a different issue.
You don't want... you're saying, we're the State, you can't touch us, so we don't get to the question of whether you're a person under 1983, whether you're barred.
That's... I could understand your argument better if you said, what we were really trying to do was to get those officers, with their individual capacity complaints, over into the Federal court.
Of course we're not going to say we can manipulate the process by immunizing the State from having any court--

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --That's precisely what we were trying to do, Your Honor.
The claims as to the State, the official capacity claims and the claims against the State agency, were irrelevant to the removal decision.
The point was, we were going to have litigation on the individual capacity claims.
Those are the ones that the district court spent time on.
The district court spent a paragraph on the official capacity claims.
So did we in our briefs, essentially.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --So what... I'm not certain.
Please correct me if I--

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --don't understand the posture of this, but I thought that these... that the plaintiff has sued the State, i.e. the official capacity ones, and also a number of individuals, and then the whole case is removed to Federal court.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And everybody wins, the defendants won.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right.
Now, the Seventh Circuit sent the whole case back to the State court, and that was the problem.
Why should it send back the part against the individuals?
Isn't that what was bothering everybody?
I mean, the part about the State, I would think of course they should send back that claim.

I mean, that claim, you've asserted the Eleventh Amendment, has no business in Federal court, it's pendant to the others, or it's one claim out of many, and you go back to State court and try it out in the State court.
Am I right?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: It could be tried, certainly, in the State court.
However, Your Honor--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I'm trying to find out what the issue is here.
I mean, is anyone saying... I thought there is a pretty clear mistake.
The clear mistake was in sending all these other claims, the ones not involving the State, back to the State court.
Am I right about that?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --I don't believe you're right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Good.
All right.
Then explain what I'm missing.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: The issue that I see is the broader issue of what kind of a system are we going to have that is simple and effective for removal, that is simple and effective for determining jurisdictional questions, that is simple and effective for determining Eleventh Amendment immunity.
What happens in this individual case is actually irrelevant--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Maybe there's no way of straightening me out.
I'm trying to figure out what happened in the individual case.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --Fine.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I thought there are actions against the State and there are actions against people that aren't the State, and I thought the Seventh Circuit sent the whole kit and caboodle back to State court.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: It did.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, that's wrong, isn't it?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: It was wrong in doing that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right.
But is there anything wrong about their sending back the action against the State to State court?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: As a matter of jurisdiction, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: As a matter of discretion, it may not have been.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Ah.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: They turned on jurisdiction and said, there was not removal jurisdiction at the threshold of this case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right, so they should have used a different reason.

The normal way to do it would be to say, well, we decide all the other claims, but the one about the State itself on official capacity, that's barred by the Eleventh Amendment, so we send that one back like a pendant claim.
That's your view of how it should have worked.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Yes.
If, in fact, there is authority to do that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So you're going to end up--

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --as a matter of discretion.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Yes, and so you're going to end up in the State court anyway.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: We might.
The result might be the same, but as a matter of discretion, leaving intact the vital differences between jurisdictional analysis, discretionary analysis, Eleventh Amendment immunity analysis.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Then you're changing the answer to the question.
Originally you said, no, no, we're saying Federal court.
The only thing you can do with the State is dismiss it, not remand, and now I think in response to Justice Breyer's question, you're kind of saying, well, maybe not.
Maybe there's discretion to remand.
But you have no discretion unless you have authority in the first place.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: That's correct, Justice Ginsburg, and it is precisely the point, and I thank you for tightening that.
On the issue of jurisdiction, do we... did the district court have jurisdiction?
Must the appellate court remand one or more of these claims as a matter of jurisdiction?
Must they?
No.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, may I interrupt you on that point?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It may be that there are two different jurisdictional issues involved here.
1441 talks, I think quite plainly, about constitutional subject matter jurisdiction.
That's what you're assuming and I agree with you.

But 1447(c) talks simply about subject matter jurisdiction, not original jurisdiction but subject matter jurisdiction, and it may well be that, given the way this Court has construed the Eleventh Amendment, that there was Federal question jurisdiction for 1441 purposes so that the case was properly removed, but once the Eleventh Amendment defense was raised, the court no longer had subject matter jurisdiction within the meaning of 1447(c), and therefore was obligated to remand for that purpose.
Would that be a possibility?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: I don't believe it would fall within the 1447 issue because I do believe subject matter jurisdiction in 1447(c) goes to subject matter jurisdiction over the action, not over a particular claim.
Here, unquestionably throughout the case--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, is the... but isn't that a matter of semantics?
I mean, it's an action insofar as it's against the State, and insofar as it's against State officers in official capacity.
That's the case against them, and so far as the case against them is concerned, isn't subject matter jurisdiction lost once the Eleventh Amendment defense is raised?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --I don't believe so, Your Honor, because claims within an action are not parceled out in that fashion.
I believe the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you just agreed... I thought you just agreed with Justice Breyer that they could be parceled out in that fashion, because we can split the claims against the individuals, the individual responsibility claims from the Government claims, so you're parceling them out.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --When we get to the discretionary issue, far from the jurisdictional issue.
In other words, when we're looking at jurisdiction to begin with--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why can it be parceled when the court is acting on the discretionary power but not be parceled when the court is considering whether it has a mandate?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --Based on this Court's decisions that, for example, in City of Chicago the court had original... had Federal question jurisdiction over the entire action, over all the claims in the action because of the Federal claims.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But surely it's not your position, Mr. Moriarty, that the Eleventh Amendment is a bar to the claims against the individual defendants.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Certainly not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And those, then, would be litigated in the district court under a correct ruling?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: The... those claims... the district court had Federal question jurisdiction on removal.

Therefore, it could dispose of the Eleventh Amendment barred claims on... it could dispose... the claims against the State, either based on the definition in 1983 or based on the Eleventh Amendment immunity.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But now, let's put the... the Eleventh Amendment immunity that you pleaded in your view requires dismissal of the action as against the State and the official capacity defendant.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But it does not require dismissal as to the individual defendants.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So the district court could properly adjudicate those claims.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: The... certainly the individual capacity claims, yes.
The--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: May I ask this: under Wisconsin law, can the Attorney General, by his or her own determination, waive the Eleventh Amendment in Federal court?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --No.
That's been... it's in the statutes and it's also been litigated.
The Attorney General does not have authority to waive Eleventh... sovereign immunity.
Under the Wisconsin constitution only the legislature has the authority to--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So only the legislature can waive the Eleventh Amendment by special statute?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --Right, either waive the Eleventh Amendment or sovereign immunity, correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Who do you--
--May I ask why 1441(c) is relevant at all?
I mean, it seems to me 1441(c) didn't envision the reason for non-Federal jurisdiction, which we have here?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: I'm sorry if I misspoke.
I meant 1447(c).
I think that's what we're referring to.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Ah, okay.
No, I thought there was some discussion about remanding the portions of the cause of action which do not consist of Federal claims to the State court.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Correct.
1441(c) I did not see as relevant either and did not put in my brief.
Pages 5 and 6 cite the portions of 1441(a) and (b) and 1447(c), which I believe to be relevant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, isn't (c) relevant to the extent that it establishes the fact that the district judge could have sent back... could have remanded the claims against the State, the official capacity claims?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: I believe that the 1441(c) addresses an entirely different situation, and involves when there's a separable controversy, when there's not, that type of thing, whereas in this case it's clear we have one single controversy, the firing of the respondent.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, but we have a case, the Coville case which says that the statute does not preclude a remand that isn't covered by the precise... that these... the statute covers must remands.
It doesn't necessarily cover may remands.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: That's the central point I'm trying to make, that the... this decision by the Seventh Circuit was wrong because it looked at what must occur as a matter of threshold jurisdiction, mixed together the discretionary issues, mixed together the Eleventh Amendment immunity jurisdictional issues, and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But may I just clarify one thing in your position?
Do you agree the district court could have remanded and should have remanded the claims against the State that are barred by the Eleventh Amendment in Federal court?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --I do not believe they should have remanded it.

I think what they should have done, if they had jurisdictional questions, which they surely did, looked at the issue, looked immediately at the 1983 definition and said, we don't have anything here against the State, and moved to the merits of the appeal.
If they wanted to look at Eleventh Amendment immunity, then they could have said, well, that's fine, but that comes later in the jurisdictional analysis.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Who do you represent?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: We represent the Wisconsin agency, the officials in their official capacity, but the primary motivation on removal was the officials in their individual capacity.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right.
You represent them, too.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Fine.

Then I took from your cert position your basic point... maybe you're being too subtle about it here, but I took your basic point to be from the cert petition that at least the Seventh Amendment was mistaken in ordering the personal claims sent back, that they shouldn't... even if they're right about having the Eleventh Amendment claims sent back, that's just one claim, or one set of claims--

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --in a multiclaim suit, and they can't say you have to send them all back.
Wasn't that your basic claim before you even get into this?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: That is absolutely fundamental ground floor--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Okay.

Now, once you'd say we win on that we have a separate argument, and the separate argument is, they shouldn't have even sent back the State claim, and the reason for that is, if they'd looked at it for 3 minutes they would have seen that the Eleventh Amendment part is irrelevant, because you can't assert the Eleventh Amendment in defense to a claim that doesn't exist, and the claim doesn't exist because of your interpretation of 1983.
Now, is that your argument?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --With this variation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Eleventh Amendment can bar those claims.
It's simply unnecessary.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It's unnecessary.
There's an alternative ground.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: And the point is--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But your first argument is the main argument, and your second... I mean, and don't tell me I'm right if I'm not.
I want to be certain I'm understanding this.
Is that... have I now stated what your argument is, basically?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The first part is, they shouldn't have sent the whole thing back.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The second part is, if we win on that one, they shouldn't have even sent the State part back.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Okay.

Well, but now, if you have two grounds, one is the Eleventh Amendment and another is a ground of statutory construction, one is, we've said, quasi-jurisdictional and the other is simply an argument on the law.
I would think that the Eleventh Amendment argument would prevail over the statutory construction argument.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: That would be the case except for this Court's decisions in Ngirainga v. Sanchez, in which it took up that definitional issue first, over the strenuous objections of the dissent, and that wanted the immunity issues addressed first in Ngiraingas.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Was this post-Steel Co., not--

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: It was not post-Steel--
[Laughter]
Last month.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Yes.
Well, I thought Steel Co. was our last word.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Indeed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And I thought we said you address, unsurprisingly, jurisdictional issues first.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And in this one, if you take the words of the Constitution it says the judicial power of the United States shall not extend to any suit, so that sounds... there is no power over such a suit.
How you would get to the 1983 person question if there is no power to do anything is a bit of a mystery.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Which--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, it's the same question.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --Okay.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You can answer... look at either one of us.
I don't care.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: In the Idaho case the Court looked at the words, in particular the word extends in Article III and looked at the word extends in the Eleventh Amendment and said, they seem similar, yes, it must be the same thing.
It's not.
The Eleventh Amendment immunity has never been held to be a bar to jurisdiction over an action at the threshold, and that's what we're dealing with here.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, because you could waive it.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: We could waive it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We don't know whether it's that kind of bar until the State doesn't waive it, correct?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: And also it is a defense.
It's... it can be waived.
Very difficult to waive it.
It can be waived, and also it is a defense, and in the removal setting particularly, as just noted in Rivet, a defense, removal jurisdiction is not determined based on a defense.
It's based on--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: By failing to raise the Eleventh Amendment as a defense, the... it may not be the same thing as a waiver, where you expressly renounce reliance on it, but by, if you fail to raise the defense at any time during the proceedings, the proceedings stand.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --That's--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It's not like a case where there simply was no subject matter jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --Absolutely correct, Chief Justice, and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Here you did raise it.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --We did raise it.
We raised it again throughout, as is the case in most Eleventh Amendment cases where the court has addressed the issues.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: One part of this before you finish that I don't quite understand.
Since you're so clear on the 1983, not a person argument, why didn't you, over in the Wisconsin State court, say, Wisconsin State court, get the State out of it, we're not a 1983 person?
Then you'd have a clean suit that the individuals... that the defendants being sued in their individual capacity could remove.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Because the removal decision must be made very promptly.
The statute requires that it be made within, I believe it's 20 or 30 days after you first learn of the lawsuit.
You don't have time to litigate in front of the State court, get rid of claims.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So you say... are you saying that the individuals would have been untimely if they didn't petition to remove until after the State was dismissed?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Yes.

If the case was not removable at the time, then it might have been deferred, but to risk the fact that it was "not removable" by failing to remove at that time would have been a poor litigation decision.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You made the right litigation decision, we'll assume.
You removed... now the Eleventh Amendment defense is raised, why... tell me... explain at that point why the court is not bound to remand.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Because the court had Federal question jurisdiction over all of the claims under--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But it no longer has... if the Eleventh Amendment issue is correct, it no longer would have subject matter jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --Over one or two of the claims made in the case, but certainly--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Oh, look, over the State and the official capacity defendants.
It would no longer have subject matter jurisdiction over them, would it?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --We... it would have... no longer have subject matter jurisdiction over the claims made against the State.
However, that's because of a defense that's been interposed.
The issue of original jurisdiction, the issue of removal jurisdiction goes to the entire action.
That's what City of Chicago was talking about.
The State law claims certainly weren't within the original jurisdiction.
It was only when we had the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, but these--
--But the point is... the point is, removal was allowable, initially.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --Mm-hmm.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And once the State in Federal court says, wait a minute, Eleventh Amendment as to State claims, then those claims could be remanded to the State court and you can go deal with it back in State court, leave the individual capacity claims in the Federal court.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Certainly--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Isn't that adequate?
I mean, doesn't that take care of everything?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --In this particular case, it's not going to make much difference.
We can do it.
We can go back to court.
We can handle that, but--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You can go back to State court and make your pitch on person.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --And we'll prevail.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And why shouldn't that be done?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: I know we'll--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In other words, why shouldn't it be done?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --Why shouldn't it be done?
Because it mixes together the essential issues of jurisdiction removal and Eleventh Amendment immunity.
If, in fact, the Eleventh Amendment immunity--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Stand back from it--
--Yes.
Yes.
--and our colloquy before.
You are saying, because of the Eleventh Amendment, no court can deal with a 1983 person.
We just get out.
We just get out at the threshold.

We take it out of the State court, put it into the Federal court, and then say, Federal court, you dismiss, and then we're not subject to having that question decided by any court, ever, and that's a very hard argument to make.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --I don't believe that's the result.
We are asking that a Federal court look at those issues and resolve them.
If, in fact, it's a dismissal without prejudice--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you're asking for Eleventh Amendment immunity, and as Justice Scalia has pointed out, at least after his recent decision that would come first, before you deal with the merits.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --And if Eleventh Amendment immunity went to the jurisdiction of the court over an action, under Steel Company it would always have to be addressed first, always.
The court would never--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would you say it's not jurisdiction, since it could be waived?
You say it's not jurisdictional.
Is that what you're saying?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --I'm not... it is a jurisdictional issue.
Jurisdictional is a word of many, too many meanings.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mm-hmm.
But it's not subject matter jurisdiction, then.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: It doesn't go to jurisdiction over the action.
It goes to jurisdiction over the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Over the person.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: --particular claim.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, but you're back... I mean, your argument now is back to saying, you cannot split them up.
You're back to saying you cannot deal with the official action differently from the way you deal with the individual action.
That's the premise of your answer that you just gave, isn't it?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: The... I don't believe it is, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Then I don't understand.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Jurisdiction over the action is the first question.
Is this properly within the courthouse door?
Second question.
Let's look at the claims we have and the defenses and see what happens to those claims.
In City of Chicago we have Federal claims.
Therefore, we have the case properly within the courthouse door.
Next question.
What do we have there?
We have some State law claims as well.
Well, as long as we've got Federal question jurisdiction, we can look at those State law claims under pendant and ancillary jurisdiction.
We couldn't have if there weren't any Federal questions.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right, and this is unlike City of Chicago because once the Eleventh Amendment issue is raised, you don't have... the Federal court does not have jurisdiction to adjudicate the State and the official capacity claims, so Chicago doesn't cover this.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: It does not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And you're saying, if I understand you, that with respect to the State and the official capacity claims, it was error to remand.
Why was it error to remand?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: It was error to remand because the Seventh Circuit did it on a basis of lack of original jurisdiction, lack of removal jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right.
Should they not have done the same thing on the basis of lack of subject matter jurisdiction, not Article III jurisdiction, maybe, but at least subject matter jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: Under 1447(c)?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: richard_briles_moriarty
turn.label: Mr. Richard Briles Moriarty
turn.text: That replies again, as I read the cases, to jurisdiction over the action.
You've lost jurisdiction over the entire action before the case is completed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Moriarty.
Mr. Lasker, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

Justice Souter, I would like to begin by addressing your concern, because I do believe that this case clearly was handled correctly by the Seventh Circuit, because once removed to Federal court the State did immediately assert its Eleventh Amendment immunity, and there certainly the court lacked subject matter jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, why couldn't the Federal court retain the action and decide the individual capacity claims, remand the claims against the State, and there you are?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: I don't think--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What's the matter with that?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --I think the problem with that, Justice O'Connor, is that it doesn't pay respect to the statutes enacted by Congress that govern this matter.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I think it does entirely, and the case was removable in the first instance, but once the Eleventh Amendment defense is asserted, then the Federal court can remand so much of the case as deals with the Eleventh Amendment claims and keep the rest.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Your Honor, I--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I thought that was where the Seventh Circuit's decision appears questionable.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, I do not agree that the case was properly removed to begin with.
I think that the Court lacked original jurisdiction under 1441(a).
I think we have a very unique circumstance here which, as Justice Scalia pointed out, really hasn't been contemplated by the explicit language of any one of these statutory provisions.
This is a situation--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I think it fits.

I mean, as long as... if we don't know if the State is going to assert an Eleventh Amendment defense, and certainly the suit originally filed included section 1983 claims against individuals in their individual capacity, so the whole thing could have been filed in Federal district court as an original proposition.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --I believe that it could have been filed there only to give the Federal court jurisdiction to determine that it lacked jurisdiction because of the Eleventh Amendment problem extant in the case as originally filed.

Of course, the case was not filed in Federal court, and that's essential to the case at bar, but had the case been filed in Federal court, I believe the Federal court's jurisdiction would have only been to the extent of determining under Steel Company that it didn't have jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that's where I disagree.
It certainly had jurisdiction over the claims against the individuals in their individual capacity.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I would say that Justice Ginsburg was correct in saying that what the State should have done in this situation, or which would have been the simple way out of the woods for this difficult problem that's presented here, would have been for them to move to dismiss the claims that were supposedly improper claims which were the only claims that presented the Eleventh Amendment problem.
Then they would have been able to remove under 144--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, but I think Mr. Moriarty pointed out that the individuals might have been told you're too late to remove, because the case was removable earlier.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --Perhaps that would be true, Justice Ginsburg, prior to the decision in this case, but this Court will now reach a decision which will speak to all lawyers and judges and clarify this difficult situation where we have Federal claims that are Eleventh Amendment-barred.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is it your position that the State could have moved, or the Circuit Court of Dane County, they could have moved in that court to dismiss claims that would have been barred by the Eleventh Amendment in Federal court?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Certainly not on the grounds of the Eleventh Amendment.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: No, on--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's not binding on the State--

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --On the grounds of their argument that we failed to state a claim under section 1983, but once they had established that we'd failed to state a claim against the State, or the State defendants in their official capacities, they could have removed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --But that's saying that you have to do what litigating you can in the State court.
I don't know if that's faithful to the removal statute.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: I believe it's exactly what Congress intended, Your Honor.
I think that Congress clearly intended that the sorting out of these matters be done in State court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It couldn't have been so clear, because you missed it.
You never... you didn't resist the remand.
Nobody ever thought of it till it got to the Seventh Circuit, right?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: That's true, Your Honor, and I'm quite an expert on the Eleventh Amendment since the cert petition was granted, but I can't say that I was beforehand.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I don't understand.
I mean, I must be maybe missing something obvious.
Forget State court.

Suppose I, a plaintiff, feel my civil rights were infringed, and I want to sue a lot of people, so I march into the door of the Federal district court and I sue four policemen and the municipality, and I throw in a State official, and I add, in his official capacity, so I have seven suits, seven claims in this suit.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I would have thought... is there any law, any case, anything that says that I can't bring that lawsuit in a Federal district court?
I thought that's garden variety.

I thought it happens every day of the week that people bring suits like that in the Federal district court and then, if the State happens to assert Eleventh Amendment as to its claim, at that point, maybe we dismiss that claim, but am I wrong about my garden variety, and way this civil rights law works, because you do know a lot about that.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Well, now that I've become an expert on that Eleventh Amendment, I do--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Forgetting... yes.
Go ahead.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --I do believe that the case you cite should not be accepted in the Federal court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, is there any precedent anywhere where a judge didn't accept such a case?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: I think this would have to become the case, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So as far as we know, no; this would be historical to say that they can't have cases like that in Federal district court, and your reason for saying that is?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: My reason for saying that is that the Eleventh Amendment, Your Honor, is in the Constitution at all times, and it is in the nature of a jurisdiction bar, as this Court said in--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But Mr. Lasker, what about the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, which says that you can add and drop parties any time, so you were wrong about naming a State or a State officer.
You just drop that party.
That--

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --If that party is dropped out, then the bar to Federal jurisdiction would be gone, and then under 1446(b) it could be removed to Federal court.
If removal to Federal court--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Well, Mr. Lasker, I thought City of Chicago was relevant in one respect in this case.
It made clear that the existence of some properly stated Federal claims suffices to make actions, civil actions within the original jurisdiction of the district courts for purposes of removal.
Some Federal claims.
I thought City of Chicago spoke to that, and so your argument rings hollow to my ear--

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --Thank you--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --on that point.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --Thank you, because I really think that it's important to underscore that City of Chicago involved State claims that were attached under the Court's pendant or supplemental jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It did not involve claims which would be potentially subject to an Eleventh Amendment immunity defense.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It did not.
But in principle it's the same because unless and until the Eleventh Amendment is raised, it's okay.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, the difference between State claims, State law claims and Federal claims that may be barred under the Eleventh Amendment is a distinction that I think is important here, and... but certainly--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you deal with it by remanding the claims in which the Eleventh Amendment would cover it and go on with what's left.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --That does not pay homage, Your Honor, to the language of 1447(c), which says that when the court lacks subject matter jurisdiction the case shall be remanded.
There's not authority to remand individual claims, and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's... on reading that... that that's all.
I... shall be remanded says, when you fit this, then it must be remanded.

It doesn't say that nothing else can be remanded, and the notion that somehow this case is... doesn't belong in Federal court, even though City of Chicago does, is staggering, because here there's nothing but Federal law, is all.
There's no claim made under any law other than Federal law, as I understand this complaint.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --But this contains claims of Federal law, Justice Ginsburg, some of which may not be brought in Federal court but all of which may be brought in State court, and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, but there's no exclusive venue.
I mean, if you... you can say yes, sometimes Congress lets people sue in State court if they want to, like the FELA.
There's nothing like that here.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --The... I guess I--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You can bring a 1983 action in State court, can you not?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --Of course, yes, and this entire action was properly brought in State court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, but defendants in 1983 actions can remove them to Federal court, as defendants in FELA cases could not, because there Congress says, not only can you bring it in State court, but it can't be removed if you bring it there.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Your Honor, I think what I'm recommending to this Court is that you announce a doctrine in handling this case that is true to the unambiguous language of the statutes, that is... that honors the principles of Federalism under the Eleventh Amendment and Article III, and that applies a doctrine that is efficient and simple to understand for lawyers and judges, and that, I submit to you, is exactly what the Seventh Circuit did in this case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And I take it that as part of this clarification you are going to stick with your answer that you gave to Justice Breyer.
He said, forget State court, you go into Federal court with all of these claims, one of them, which is barred by the Eleventh Amendment, six of which are good Federal claims.

As I understood your answer to the question you said the entire case must be dismissed, and then Justice Ginsburg said, well, what about the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, and you said, well, what the State court does is to sort things out, but that was avoiding the hypothetical.

The hypothetical was, just the Federal court, so it seemed to me that you didn't answer correctly when you responded to Justice Ginsburg's suggestion, and I want to know if as part of this overall clarification you're suggesting that we say, if there's one cause of action over which the Federal court... forget the State court.
This is, initially you file it in the United States district court.
If there's one cause of action over which there's an Eleventh Amendment jurisdictional problem, Eleventh Amendment jurisdictional bar, the entire case must be dismissed.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Well, I think--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is... you have absolutely no authority for that proposition.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --I don't have a case to cite for that proposition, and this case does not raise those facts, of course, but--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure are against you.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --Your Honor, the fact is that we're dealing here with a hybrid type of case that is not... has not been addressed foursquare before in any situation that I'm aware of, and that is a case where you have Federal claims that are not barred by the Eleventh Amendment coupled with Federal claims that are barred by the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, but these cases happen all the time... all the time.
It's just because of the rather unusual step taken by the Seventh Circuit that we have it here.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --Your Honor, I believe that on behalf of my client I had a right as the plaintiff's counsel to file this case in State court, which is how this question comes here from the Seventh Circuit, and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I can understand that part of it, and that's what this case is.
This is a removal case.

But the case that I put to you, and Justice Kennedy just recalled, of an initial proceeding in Federal court with some defendants, why would it be any different than if you filed a diversity suit and you had one nondiverse defendant, and there was a motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction?
You'd say, fine, I drop the nondiverse defendant.
Why is this any different as an initial matter?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --Because I don't think that Congress intended to bifurcate the litigation in that fashion.
I think that piecemeal removal--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Forget removal.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --All right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We're in Federal court with a complaint that includes the State and individuals.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And there is a motion to dismiss the State on Eleventh Amendment grounds.
Isn't that all that would be dismissed?
If in other words, you have this case originally in Federal court.
The State gets out when it moves to dismiss on Eleventh Amendment grounds.
The other defendants don't.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: I suppose the answer to that question would be yes, and that does--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --then draw the importance of the fact that this case arises out of my choice to sue in State court and then the defendant's procedural maneuver that was disapproved of in this case and that was of concern to the Seventh Circuit in Frances J., that the defendants remove a case of that sort from State court to Federal court really for the purpose of separating the prospective relief claims from the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well then, your argument should address why it should be different on removal than it would have been if the case were originally filed in Federal court, and--

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --Okay.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --perhaps pointing to some statutory language.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Some statutory language that somehow overrules the extant statutory language that says that any civil action brought in a State court of which the district courts of the United States have original jurisdiction may be removed, so we need a statute that somehow undoes that, but you've conceded it could have been brought in the United States district court.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --Well, the statute that disposes of this case is 1447(c).

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It's critical to your position, as I understand it, that if there is an Eleventh Amendment defense potentially available to one of the defendants, that the court lacks subject matter jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: That's my position, Justice Stevens.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And that we have not yet held.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And that would be true in an original filing under Federal... in Federal court, surely, just as true as if the action were removed from State court.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: I believe it would, but I think that that would deal with the kind of case that we've got here in the most efficient way--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You're changing your answer, then.

I mean, I think if you give away that... the answer to Justice Ginsburg's and Justice Breyer's question of what would have happened had this suit been originally brought in district court, I think your case is gone.
You have to defend the position that this action would not have been originally bringable in a Federal court.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --I do assert that it should not have been accepted under the court's original jurisdiction, and I say that whether I'm right about that or not, Justice Scalia, certainly when the State asserted its Eleventh Amendment defenses in Federal court, then clearly under 1447(c) the Federal court lacked subject matter jurisdiction and was right to send the entire case back, not just the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right, can I say... I'm trying to find some authority for you.
I mean, here you got another shot at this from the Seventh Circuit, so I don't blame you at all for defending this, but I'm trying to think of the authority that might support you.
Is there any authority in the following proposition?

I now go to the Federal district court and I file my claim, which I have my four defendants, lots of Federal law, and one of my 19 claims... one of them... there is no subject matter jurisdiction over, for whatever set of reasons.
Forget the Eleventh Amendment.
Is there any authority, when that situation arises... I would have thought all that happens is, they dismiss that claim and proceed with the rest.
But is there any authority for the proposition that you have to dismiss the whole thing?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --No, not that I'm aware of, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right.

Now, to take them... is there any authority for the proposition that when you remove such a case from the State court to the Federal court you have to dismiss the whole thing, i.e., you couldn't remove it?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: No, there isn't, but--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Then I think you're on a tough ground.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --That's... my answer to you is correct, but I again have to ask you not to hang me on my answer to that question--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, no, I wouldn't because I mean, you say, well, this will be quite simple.
I'm not sure it would be simple.

There are a lot of cases, you know, where you don't quite know whether this is a State official, not a State official, official capacity, not official capacity, everybody gets mixed up and they have huge arguments, and the whole case would have to be sent back to another court.
That's worrying me.

I suppose one of the things that's wrong is that the State, by quite a sensible rule, it seems to me, should be deemed to have waived its Eleventh Amendment immunity the minute it consents to the removal, but that's not our law, either.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --No, it doesn't seem to be, Your Honor, so that's the situation we're stuck with.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Lasker, you have a statement in your brief that the State was not immune from suit in State court.
Isn't there a sovereign immunity doctrine that's applicable in the State court?
I mean--

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Well, it... there is a sovereign immunity statute in the State court for State claims.
I'm not sure exactly where in my brief you're referring, but--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --On the top of page 9 you say that the Seventh Circuit held the district court lacked original jurisdiction because petitioners were immune from suit in the Federal court, and then you add, although they were not immune from suit in the State court.
Of course, they don't have Eleventh Amendment immunity, but--

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --That's what I was referring to.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --most States have their own sovereign immunity doctrine, don't they?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: They do, but I was... but the State immunity is, I believe, abrogated by section 1983, although a State is not a person under section 1983 since Will.

What I was talking about, however, is that the action as it was brought would have been within the jurisdiction of the State court and was not within the jurisdiction of the Federal court for the reason of the existence of the Eleventh Amendment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There isn't something like a Wisconsin tort claims act that would allow a wrongful discharge case to be brought against the State?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: I do have a theory, Your Honor, that I seek to assert in the State court upon remand, that we do have a claim under the Wisconsin constitution that would not be barred by the State doctrine of sovereign immunity.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is your... are the circuit courts in Wisconsin courts of general jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Where you don't have limitations of subject matter the way you do in the Federal court?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Lasker, what prevents us from holding that when a State removes or consents to removal of a case into Federal court it waives its Eleventh Amendment objection?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: I just... I don't know that anything stands in the way of that except stare decisis.

I think that the Finney case and other cases that are cited in the brief do stand for the proposition that the waiver has to be an explicit act of the sovereign State and not just something that happens because of the strategic decision by an Assistant Attorney General, for example.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I mean, isn't it clear that when you say, I want to be in Federal court, you mean I want to be in Federal court?

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Well, it would seem clear to me, Your Honor, but I don't think that that's ever been considered to be a proper waiver of the State's Eleventh Amendment immunity.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We wouldn't have any of these troubles if that were the rule.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: Perhaps not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If it were, then maybe Mr. Moriarty could not have removed the case, because he said that under State law they have no authority, the State AG has no authority to waive the Eleventh Amendment.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: I'm not an authority on that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It follows from that, doesn't it, that if that's true, then it was clear even before the removal, because of the State law situation, that there would never have been jurisdiction in the Federal court over part of the case, because the... because it's foreordained that it's not optional, as your opponent suggests, that they may or may not waive it.
The law of Wisconsin required him to assist... assert his Eleventh Amendment jurisdiction and, therefore, following the reasoning of the Seventh Circuit, they had to send the whole case back.
They could not accept the removal because there was a jurisdictional bar.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --I'd say that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You don't know which side I'm on here.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --Well, I do say that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It seems to--

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --that the case should not have been accepted into Federal court until the State court--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --had sorted out the claims--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Because as a matter of Wisconsin law, it's clear that the Federal court never had... could have taken jurisdiction of the claim against the State, as a matter of Wisconsin law, which they would have to honor, that they could not waive the Eleventh Amendment defense.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: --Well, I don't know that Wisconsin law is as Mr. Moriarty asserts.
I'm going to accept his word on that, but I don't think it would be difficult for the State to waive and get a statute enacted by the legislature.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Of course, the Federal court would have had jurisdiction if the State had simply processed its removal and made no objection on Eleventh Amendment grounds.
It doesn't have to waive in the sense of affirmatively renouncing.
It can simply do nothing and the Eleventh Amendment defense is waived.

turn.speaker: david_e_lasker
turn.label: Mr. David E. Lasker
turn.text: I think that's at least clear in determining the application of 1447(c) to the facts in this case.

However, I am arguing that I think the problem exists in the case of whether the court has original jurisdiction under 1441(a), and that the best rule would be to require that the State court dismiss any claims that would otherwise be barred in the Eleventh Amendment before removal could occur.
If there are no further questions, then I'll sit down.
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Lasker.
The case is submitted.
